instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc area started smoking after plugging in battery
threads.message:
I have this 15" MBP Retina which says this is a 2016 version when I google the LB number. When I got it initially it would would not turn on with the battery plugged in so I had to unplug the battery, plug the charger in and hit the power button for it to turn on. The power button was kind of inconsistent. I was able to boot as guest user and plug the charger in and it said to "replace now".

I got the new battery but before plugging it in I removed the logic board and put flux and heated the corroded areas of the keyboard connector as well as around <RESISTOR>R9192</RESISTOR>/<CHIP>U9600</CHIP>.

The <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> area around the battery current sensing were all damaged so I replaced the ISL along with all the caps/resistors on the right side(<CAPACITOR>C7101</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>).

I had to use a schematic for an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> since I don't have a schematic for this model. I believe they are very similar judging by the donor board I am using.

After all that I went to test this out. I plugged in the display cable, keyboard cable and the new battery and while I was in the process of plugging in the trackpad cable I started seeing smoke come from the SMC area and I quickly unplugged the battery. 
Things smelled burned and the keyboard backlight part was slightly melted right around the smc area which is why I know the smc was the fault.

I removed the edge bonding and saw that Pin 2 of L5001 and Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR> both have burned pads. Again I had to use a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boardview to find that out and I am not sure where I can run a wire for those since the pad is gone.

Now when I plug in a charger I get no light on the charger.

I'm not sure why the SMC area would smoke up like that when there was no liquid damage around it nor did I do any repairs in that area. All I did was plug in a battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc area started smoking after plugging in battery
threads.message: You had power connected while plugging shit in, why?? I'm guessing you fried the SMC and L5001.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc area started smoking after plugging in battery
threads.message:
I don't know why I didnt think that was an issue. I didn't get to plug the trackpad cable in before it started smoking. 
I've never replaced an SMC before nor do I have the tools. Could you advise me on where I should get the tools and if its possible for me to take an SMC from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> or <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> because I don't have a donor for this board number.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc area started smoking after plugging in battery
threads.message: You need an exact donor board. You need experience, so practice on scrap board. I assume Louis has videos on replacing SMCs. Links to reball stencils are in the Tools section.
